facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 233 of 1960 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 233 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the award dated

facts.text: Appeal from award dated September 29, 1958 of Industrial Tribunal, Mysore in Reference I.T. No. 21 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated September 29, 1958, of the Industrial Tribunal, Mysore, in Reference  I.T.  No. 21 of 1957.

facts.text: Dispute between appellant and its workmen as to bonus for the year 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: There was a dispute between the appellant and its workmen as to bonus for the year 1954-55. This dispute was referred by the Government of

facts.text: Dispute referred by Government of Mysore under Industrial Disputes Act No. XIV of 1947 to tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was referred by the Government of Mysore under the Industrial Disputes Act No. XIV of 1947  to a tribunal for adjudication.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed Rs. 1.67 lacs for income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal allowed Rs. 1.67 lacs for income-tax. The companytention of the appellant is that this is incorrect

facts.text: Gross profits of appellant were Rs. 9.46 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the gross profits of the appellant were Rs. 9.46 lacs, while the full statutory depreciation allowed to the

facts.text: Full statutory depreciation allowed to appellant was Rs. 4.30 lacs for the year.

anchor.surface_text: lacs, while the full statutory depreciation allowed to the appellant for the year in dispute was Rs. 4.30 lacs. Thus income-tax

facts.text: Income-tax calculated on Rs. 5.16 lacs at seven annas in the rupee equaling Rs. 2.25 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: Thus income-tax should have been deducted on the sum of Rs. 5.16 lacs at seven annas in the rupee, which was the rate prevalent in the relevant year. This amount companyes to Rs. 2.25 lacks.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed three per cent return on working capital.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has allowed three per cent on working capital. The appellant companytends that the tribunal should have allowed four per cent.

facts.text: Appellant originally claimed working capital of Rs. 43.85 lacs, later revised to Rs. 36.70 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: Turning number to the amount of working capital on which return should have been allowed, the appellant originally claimed that the amount used as working capital was Rs. 43.85 lacs. Latter however, a revised statement was put in and the amount was reduced to Rs. 36.70 lacs.

facts.text: Tribunal calculated working capital as Rs. 7.85 lacs by excluding depreciation reserve of Rs. 36.24 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has however calculated the working capital used in the business as Rs. 7.85 lacs. The main reason why the tribunal arrived at this figure was that it held that the amount in the depreciation reserve companyld number be treated as reserve used as working capital on which a return was admissible. It therefore excluded out of companysideration the entire amount in the depreciation reserve which was Rs. 36.24 lacs

facts.text: Evidence by Shri M. S. Vartak, Secretary of appellant, on utilisation of reserve as working capital was accepted by tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: On that point there was the evidence of Shri M. S. Vartak who was the Secretary of the Appellant companypany. That evidence as to utilisation of the reserve as working capital was accepted by the tribunal.

facts.text: Rs. 36.70 lacs used as working capital during the year per Shri Vartak's statement.

anchor.surface_text: The statement of Shri Vartak shows that the amount shown in the revised calculations as to the working capital was actually used as working capital during the year. Thus, according to this statement, Rs. 36.70 lacs were used as working capital

facts.text: Rs. 36.70 lacs working capital includes Rs. 14.56 lacs borrowed money on which interest was paid.

anchor.surface_text: but we are of opinion that the appellant is number entitled to a return on this entire amount, for the reason that this amount includes a sum of Rs. 14.56 lacs which was either borrowed by the appellant or was in deposit with it, on which the appellant was paying interest.

facts.text: Net working capital for return: Rs. 22.14 lacs (36.70 minus 14.56) at 3% = Rs. 0.66 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the amount on which the appellant is entitled to the return on working capital as a prior charge is Rs. 36.70 lacs minus Rs. 14.56 lacs, i.e. Rs. 22.14 lacs. The return on this amount at three per cent companyes to .66 lacs

facts.text: No evidence led on rehabilitation by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Turning number to the claim for rehabilitation it is enough to say that numberevidence as to rehabilitation was led in this case.

facts.text: Return on working capital at 3% Rs. 0.66 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: Deduct-return on working capital at 3 .66

facts.text: Available surplus Rs. 1.90 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: Available surplus 1.90

facts.text: One month's wages approximately Rs. 0.64 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: One months wages companye to roughly Rs. .64 lacs. It seems to us therefore that it will be fair to allow 1 1/2 months wages as bonus for this year,

facts.text: One month's bonus already paid.

anchor.surface_text: the claim it was making on other items of prior charges would be sufficient to resist the claim for further bonus besides one months bonus already paid.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 15, 1961 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: Janardan Sharma, for respondent No. 1. 1961. November 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave in an industrial matter.
Appeal by special leave from the award dated September 29, 1958, of the Industrial Tribunal, Mysore,
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave in an industrial matter.
This dispute was referred by the Government of Mysore under the Industrial Disputes Act No. XIV of 1947  to a tribunal for adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: A number of objections were raised by the appellant before the tribunal but we are not concerned with them, as the law with respect to profit bonus has been settled by this Court in the Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. Its workmen 1 .

concepts.interpretation: Law settled by Supreme Court; court confines to specific prior charges in calculations

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ribunal. We shall therefore companyfine ourselves to the three points which have been raised before us on behalf of the appellant. The tribunal allowe

concepts.unlisted_description: Legal framework for calculating profit bonus as settled in prior Supreme Court judgments

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal allowed Rs. 1.67 lacs for income-tax. The contention of the appellant is that this is incorrect in view of the decision of this Court in the Associated Cement Companies Ltd. [...] Thus income-tax should have been deducted on the sum of Rs. 5.16 lacs at seven annas in the rupee, which was the rate prevalent in the relevant year. This amount comes to Rs. 2.25 lacs.

concepts.interpretation: Deducted on gross profits minus full statutory depreciation; tribunal's Rs. 1.67 lacs incorrect, correct is Rs. 2.25 lacs

concepts.unlisted_label: Income-tax as Prior Charge in Bonus Calculation

anchor.surface_text: The next question is about return on working capital. The dispute is both as to the rate of return and the amount on which it should be allowed. The tribunal has allowed three per cent on working capital. The appellant contends that the tribunal should have allowed four per cent. As was pointed out in the Associated Cement Companies case the rate allowed by tribunals on working capital is between two to four per cent.

concepts.interpretation: Rate between 2-4%; 3% allowed by tribunal, no interference with discretion

The main reason why the tribunal arrived at this figure was that it held that the amount in the depreciation reserve could not be treated as reserve used as working capital [...] This view of the tribunal is clearly incorrect in view of this Courts decision in The Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen.

concepts.interpretation: Depreciation reserve qualifies for return if actually used as working capital

anchor.surface_text: the same view was taken by this Court in Petlad Turkey Red Dye Works Ltd. v. Dyes and Chemical Workers Union, where it was emphasised that the balance-sheet did not by itself prove the fact of utilisation of reserve as working capital and the law required that such an important fact as the utilisation of a portion of the reserve as working capital had to be proved by the employer by evidence given on affidavit or otherwise and after giving an opportunity to the workmen to contest the correctness of such evidence by cross- examination.

concepts.interpretation: Employer must prove utilisation by evidence; workmen given opportunity to contest/cross-examine

anchor.surface_text: It may be accepted that the sum of Rs. 36.70 lacs was used as working capital by the appellant during the year but we are of opinion that the appellant is not entitled to a return on this entire amount, for the reason that this amount includes a sum of Rs. 14.56 lacs which was either borrowed by the appellant or was in deposit with it, on which the appellant was paying interest. [...] Where borrowed money is used as working capital there is no question of giving any further return on this borrowed money.

concepts.interpretation: No additional return on borrowed funds already bearing interest, included in gross profits expense

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: wed. The tribunal has allowed three per cent on working capital. The appellant companytends that the tribunal

concepts.unlisted_description: Depreciation allowance under tax law used in bonus prior charge computation

issues.text: Whether the tribunal's calculation of Rs. 1.67 lacs for income-tax as prior charge is correct, or should it be Rs. 2.25 lacs?

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal allowed Rs. 1.67 lacs for income-tax. The contention of the appellant is that this is incorrect in view of the decision of this Court in the Associated Cement Companies Ltd. It appears that the gross profits of the appellant were Rs. 9.46 lacs, while the full statutory depreciation allowed to the appellant for the year in dispute was Rs. 4.30 lacs.

issues.text: Whether the rate of return on working capital allowed by the tribunal at 3% should be increased to 4% as contended by the appellant?

anchor.surface_text: The next question is about return on working capital. The dispute is both as to the rate of return and the amount on which it should be allowed. The tribunal has allowed three per cent on working capital. The appellant contends that the tribunal should have allowed four per cent. As was pointed out in the Associated Cement Companies case the rate allowed by tribunals on working capital is between two to four per cent.

issues.text: Whether the amount in the depreciation reserve can be treated as working capital eligible for return?

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has however calculated the working capital used in the business as Rs. 7.85 lacs. The main reason why the tribunal arrived at this figure was that it held that the amount in the depreciation reserve could not be treated as reserve used as working capital [...] This view of the tribunal is clearly incorrect in view of this Courts decision in The Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen.

issues.text: Whether utilization of depreciation reserve as working capital must be proved by evidence with opportunity for workmen to contest?

anchor.surface_text: the same view was taken by this Court in Petlad Turkey Red Dye Works Ltd. v. Dyes and Chemical Workers Union, where it was emphasised that the balance-sheet did not by itself prove the fact of utilisation of reserve as working capital and the law required that such an important fact as the utilisation of a portion of the reserve as working capital had to be proved by the employer by evidence given on affidavit or otherwise and after giving an opportunity to the workmen to contest the correctness of such evidence by cross- examination.

issues.text: Whether a return on working capital is allowable on the portion that consists of borrowed money on which interest is already paid?

anchor.surface_text: It may be accepted that the sum of Rs. 36.70 lacs was used as working capital by the appellant during the year but we are of opinion that the appellant is not entitled to a return on this entire amount, for the reason that this amount includes a sum of Rs. 14.56 lacs which was either borrowed by the appellant or was in deposit with it, on which the appellant was paying interest. [...] Where borrowed money is used as working capital there is no question of giving any further return on this borrowed money.

issues.text: Whether any amount for rehabilitation should be allowed as a prior charge in the absence of evidence?

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the claim for rehabilitation it is enough to say that no evidence as to rehabilitation was led in this case. [...] In the present case, however, it is not possible to allow any amount for rehabilitation as a prior charge.

arguments.claim: Tribunal's allowance of Rs. 1.67 lacs for income-tax as prior charge is incorrect; correct amount is Rs. 2.25 lacs on Rs. 5.16 lacs after full statutory depreciation.

arguments.qualifiers: it seems to us therefore that it will be fair

arguments.claim: Return on reserves used as working capital allowable as alternative to borrowing and paying interest.

anchor.surface_text: This view of the tribunal is clearly incorrect in view of this Courts decision in The Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen. In that case it was pointed out that- a return is allowed on the reserves used as working capital on the ground

holdings.text: The tribunal's allowance of Rs. 1.67 lacs for income-tax is incorrect; correct deduction is Rs. 2.25 lacs on Rs. 5.16 lacs (gross profits Rs. 9.46 lacs minus full statutory depreciation Rs. 4.30 lacs) at seven annas in the rupee.

anchor.surface_text: Thus income-tax should have been deducted on the sum of Rs. 5.16 lacs at seven annas in the rupee, which was the rate prevalent in the relevant year. This amount comes to Rs. 2.25 lacs. The contention of the appellant in this behalf is in our opinion correct and the calculation made by the tribunal will have to be modified accordingly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gross profits minus full statutory depreciation yields taxable base; tax at prevailing rate per Associated Cement precedent.

holdings.text: No interference with tribunal's discretion to allow 3% return on working capital instead of 4%.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that there is any reason for us to interfere with the discretion of the tribunal in this matter though it is true that the recent trend of tribunals is to allow four per cent return on working capital.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rate within accepted range of 2-4% per Associated Cement; tribunal discretion not to be disturbed without reason.

holdings.text: Depreciation reserve qualifies as working capital eligible for return if actually used as such.

anchor.surface_text: This view of the tribunal is clearly incorrect in view of this Courts decision in The Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen. In that case it was pointed out that- a return is allowed on the reserves used as working capital on the ground that if these reserves are not used for this purpose, the concern would have to borrow money and pay interest on that.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Tata Oil Mills, return allowed on reserves used as working capital to avoid borrowing costs; tribunal erred in blanket exclusion.

holdings.text: Utilisation of reserve as working capital must be proved by employer through evidence (affidavit or otherwise), with opportunity for workmen to contest via cross-examination.

anchor.surface_text: the same view was taken by this Court in Petlad Turkey Red Dye Works Ltd. v. Dyes and Chemical Workers Union, where it was emphasised that the balance-sheet did not by itself prove the fact of utilisation of reserve as working capital and the law required that such an important fact as the utilisation of a portion of the reserve as working capital had to be proved by the employer by evidence given on affidavit or otherwise and after giving an opportunity to the workmen to contest the correctness of such evidence by cross- examination.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balance-sheet insufficient; requires independent evidence and audi alteram partem per Petlad precedent.

holdings.text: No return allowable on borrowed money (Rs. 14.56 lacs) used as working capital, as interest already paid and accounted in gross profits.

anchor.surface_text: It may be accepted that the sum of Rs. 36.70 lacs was used as working capital by the appellant during the year but we are of opinion that the appellant is not entitled to a return on this entire amount, for the reason that this amount includes a sum of Rs. 14.56 lacs which was either borrowed by the appellant or was in deposit with it, on which the appellant was paying interest. [...] Where borrowed money is used as working capital there is no question of giving any further return on this borrowed money.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Return only on own funds; borrowed portion already bears interest expense per Tata Oil Mills basis.

holdings.text: No allowance for rehabilitation as prior charge absent evidence; no remand as dispute relates to 1954-55 year.

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the claim for rehabilitation it is enough to say that no evidence as to rehabilitation was led in this case. [...] In the present case, however, it is not possible to allow any amount for rehabilitation as a prior charge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence required but none led; too late for remand on past year.

holdings.text: Available surplus Rs. 1.90 lacs after corrections; fair to award 1.5 months' wages (approx. Rs. 0.96 lacs) as additional bonus.

anchor.surface_text: Gross Profits Rs. 9.46 Deduct-Normal depreciation 3.32 Balance 6.14 Deduct-income-tax 2.25 Balance 3.89 Deduct-return on paid up capital 1.33 Balance 2.56 Deduct-return on working capital at 3 .66 Available surplus 1.90 One months wages come to roughly Rs. .64 lacs. It seems to us therefore that it will be fair to allow 1 1/2 months wages as bonus for this year,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recalculated surplus (gross profits minus corrected prior charges) against one month's wages (Rs. 0.64 lacs) justifies 1.5 months proportionally.

holdings.text: Appeal partly allowed; additional bonus reduced from one month to half a month.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore partly allow the appeal and reduce the additional bonus from one month to half a month.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Result of corrections to prior charges reducing surplus.

holdings.text: Absence of rehabilitation evidence in this year does not preclude leading evidence in subsequent bonus disputes.

anchor.surface_text: We should however like to make it clear that the fact that no evidence as to rehabilitation was led in this year will not preclude the appellant from leading evidence as to the amount which should be allowed to it as prior charge on account of rehabilitation, in any subsequent dispute as to bonus relating to subsequent years.

anchor.surface_text: Thus income-tax should have been deducted on the sum of Rs. 5.16 lacs at seven annas in the rupee, which was the rate prevalent in the relevant year. This amount comes to Rs. 2.25 lacs. The contention of the appellant in this behalf is in our opinion correct and the calculation made by the tribunal will have to be modified accordingly.
We therefore partly allow the appeal and reduce the additional bonus from one month to half a month.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that there is any reason for us to interfere with the discretion of the tribunal in this matter though it is true that the recent trend of tribunals is to allow four per cent return on working capital.
We therefore partly allow the appeal and reduce the additional bonus from one month to half a month.

This view of the tribunal is clearly incorrect in view of this Courts decision in The Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen. In that case it was pointed out that- a return is allowed on the reserves used as working capital on the ground that if these reserves are not used for this purpose, the concern would have to borrow money and pay interest on that.
We therefore partly allow the appeal and reduce the additional bonus from one month to half a month.

anchor.surface_text: the same view was taken by this Court in Petlad Turkey Red Dye Works Ltd. v. Dyes and Chemical Workers Union, where it was emphasised that the balance-sheet did not by itself prove the fact of utilisation of reserve as working capital and the law required that such an important fact as the utilisation of a portion of the reserve as working capital had to be proved by the employer by evidence given on affidavit or otherwise and after giving an opportunity to the workmen to contest the correctness of such evidence by cross- examination.
We therefore partly allow the appeal and reduce the additional bonus from one month to half a month.
he appellant claims return on that amount. It may be accepted that the sum of Rs. 36.70 lacs was used as working capital by the appellant during the y

anchor.surface_text: It may be accepted that the sum of Rs. 36.70 lacs was used as working capital by the appellant during the year but we are of opinion that the appellant is not entitled to a return on this entire amount, for the reason that this amount includes a sum of Rs. 14.56 lacs which was either borrowed by the appellant or was in deposit with it, on which the appellant was paying interest. [...] Where borrowed money is used as working capital there is no question of giving any further return on this borrowed money.
We therefore partly allow the appeal and reduce the additional bonus from one month to half a month.

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the claim for rehabilitation it is enough to say that no evidence as to rehabilitation was led in this case. [...] In the present case, however, it is not possible to allow any amount for rehabilitation as a prior charge.
We therefore partly allow the appeal and reduce the additional bonus from one month to half a month.
